summary:
At its core, island tourism sells beautiful scenery and pristine nature. So why does it always end up
destroying the local environment? From an early age, this self-destructive paradox has both frustrated
and fascinated me. So much so, that people even started calling me Island Girl. After years of research on this topic, I am confident that if done correctly, tourism can fuel the growth of environmental resources instead of degrading them. This is not an easy task and requires many different stakeholders cooperating across industries.

My passion for island sustainability made me very aware of how vulnerable coastal areas are to climate
change. In September 2017 the true urgency hit me. While working on a project on the island
of Dominica, I experienced Maria: a category 5 hurricane that turned the entire country to rubble in only a few hours. This was a wakeup call for me that despite the importance of research, the window for action that actually makes a difference is closing.

To help island nations become more resilient against catastrophes like the one I experienced, I look at the big picture, break it down, and identify steps that can be taken to achieve the long-term desired results. For this reason, I enjoy working on creative projects with businesses (e.g. hotels) and also at the destination-level on strategic direction. I am interested in many aspects of sustainability, but if I would have to name one main area where I want to make a difference, it would be protecting animals and their habitats ‚Äì but I believe that this goes hand in hand with creating long-term economic and social prosperity. 

My mission is support islands in protecting their environment in a way that makes both common and financial sense.
